In more geometric terms,  the spatial boundary in Poisson's problem not only must lie near a fixed plane,  but the requisite nearness depends on the first and second derivatives of the data ( see also Theorem 2',  Section 3 ). 
Theorem 3 can be generalized so as to apply without assumptions on the smoothness of the boundary.  We take this up in Section 4.  Moreover,  under the assumptions of Theorem 2 we remark that the solution of the Dirichlet problem is of class C^ in the closure of D,  and if the boundary and the data are of class C^ then the solution is even of class C^ in the closure of D. 
Since Theorem 1 is an obvious corollary of Theorem 2 and Theorem 3,  it is enough to prove the latter results.  This will be done in Sections 3 and 4.  Theorem 2,  in particular,  is a consequence of the fundamental Lemma 3,  which establishes an a priori estimate for the gradient of solutions of the Dirichlet problem in terms of the boundary data and the geometry of D,  This lemma in turn depends upon a classical barrier argument and the construction of a certain interesting supersolution of the minimal surface equation.  It is perhaps worth emphasizing that in our proof of Theorem 2 the particular structure of the minimal surface equation is used only in the construction of this supersolution.  Thus similar results for a wide class of quasilinear equations can be obtained immediately^ once corresponding supersolutions for these equations are constructed. 
In Section 5 we shall consider the situation for two dimensions.  In this case several further conclusions can be drawn in view of the availability of interior estimates for the gradient of a solution. 
The last section of the paper applies the preceding results ( especially Theorem 3 ) to show that convexity of the domain,  even in higher dimensions,  is closely connected with the solvability of Dirichlet's problem for general second order quasi - linear equations.  Thus,  if one maintains the degree of generality considered by Gilbarg and Stampacchia in their work on the Dirichlet problem,  their condition of convexity is essentially best possible. 
Finally,  the authors particularly wish to thank Professor J.  C.  G.  Nitsche for many helpful conversations during the course of this work.
